discussion.content:
An acceptable use policy (AUP) describes what employees can and cannot do with company property. Such policies include things like using a company laptop only for company business, for example. Or, an AUP could bar company employees from accessing ILLEGAL Web sites from the organization’s computers. AUPs are often very detailed and specific documents that employees must agree to and sign as a step in the employment process.
-Mike Meyers ebook

questions.question_text: Which of the following should be enacted to reduce a company's liability and exposure to a potential lawsuit?

Joe, a user, notifies Ann, a technician, of a message that is displaying on his screen. The message has taken over the entire screen, and no icons are displayed.
Joe, further explains that the message still appears after several reboot attempts. Upon further inspection of the affected PC, Ann notices a request for cryptocurrency payment to obtain the unlock key.
Which of the following is MOST likely the cause?

comments.content: she met enough mistakes to make her expert

discussion.content: I'm really happy to see that, after all of her time job hopping, Ann is finally a technician and will be able to handle the basic IT problems herself from now on. Good work Ann.
i think i'd learn more from Ann than any course i can find.
Takes learning from my mistakes to another level, literally commuting every single one at least once and asking technicians for help. What is she, the Louis Lane of the IT world.
keys as in private keys. you will not be able to unencrypt this message without a private key.

questions.question_text: A user receives an email on a company smartphone. When trying to open the email, the user gets a message stating the email is encrypted, and the user cannot open it. The user forwards the email to a personal email account and receives the same message. The user calls the IT department to ask for help. To decrypt the message, the technician tells the user to contact the sender of the message to be able to exchange:

A Linux user reports that an application will not open and gives the error. Only one instance of the application may run at one time. A root administrator logs on to the device and opens a terminal. Which of the following pairs of tools will be needed to ensure no other instances of the software are currently running?

comments.content: Correct, but the process is ended with it's PID number, not the name. The PID can be found with ps.

discussion.content:
Linux commands ps and kill are the most correct answers.
ps displays all running processes. kill can be used to end a process by name.

choices.D: Perform a full backup and replace the hard drive
choices.A: Roll back the OS upgrade. Continue using the older version of Windows
choices.B: Reset the PC to its factory conditions. Perform the OS upgrade again
choices.C: Update the SATA controller driver from the manufacturer's website

questions.question_text: A technician responds to a report that a user's desktop is operating much slower after upgrading the Windows OS to the latest version. The technician notices responsiveness is erratic, and the symptoms are similar to a failing hard drive. The technician runs a full hardware diagnostic, and all systems pass. The technician checks the properties for each device in Device Manager and the hard disk and the standard AHCI 1.0 serial ATA controller both indicate the following message: This device is working properly. Which of the following should the technician attempt that will MOST likely resolve the performance issue?

discussion.content: C. Update the SATA controller driver from the manufacturers website -- always start with the quickest and least expensive potential solution -- if that fails then move to the next best solution.
The question clearly mentions that both hard disk and AHCI SATA are working properly, so why not rollback?

comments.content: But why waste time rolling back on something that can potentially be fixed quickly and easily anyway? OS upgrades are inevitable and will need to happen sooner or later. Might as well try to fix the issue, rather than revert what eventually needs to be done.

discussion.content: Why not A? Everything about the computer seems to be working fine until the OS was upgraded. The question is asking how to resolve the Performance issues not what is the quickest or cheapest way to fix the issue. Rolling back to the previous OS would most likely resolve the Performance issues.

This is all about the phrasing of the question. The question mentions two things that indicate the drive is not failing, this is on purpose. From the data provided the drive itself is fine, replacing it would do nothing. So the answer is C.

Upon further consideration:
B. Reset the PC to its factory conditions. Perform the OS upgrade again – the tech has not identified the problem – everything the tech checked reports no errors – he just observes that “responsiveness is erratic” – so reset and re-upgrade.

comments.content: Unnecessary when the next best troubleshooting step (C.) takes far less time and effort.

discussion.content: Bah, years of being trained to "before you do ANYTHING, back it up!" is gonna cause me to fail

comments.content: Though I suppose the real devil in the details here is "full backup", that'd take WAY too long for a regular support call

It's C because the question mentions that more than one thing indicates that the drive is not failing. Replacing the drive when the drive isn't faulty would potentially keep the issue. If the drive was indicated failing then replacing the drive would be most likely.

It is so likely. The problem is with the drive and after been proven to not be failing, the drivers would most likely be the culprit. Would you reinstall Windows every time your printer fails to print? No, you would update or reinstall the printer driver if the spooler service is not causing the issue.

The question asks "...will MOST likely RESOLVE the performance issue" not what should be the first thing to try. The first thing to try might be the driver, but it's not likely to be the thing which RESOLVES the problem.
Try updating the driver is quick and free. Lowest impact/cost method first.

discussion.content: The answer doesn't make sense for this question. Shouldn't it be D. Run a Full Back-up and replace the Hard Drive?
